title: nativeIsNaN is not defined in lodash.underscore.js
body: nativeIsNaN is not defined in lodash.underscore.js isFinite function.

title: Improve startup time of lodash-node
body:
Browser version of minified lodash takes 5-7 ms to load in my browser (Chrome). On the same machine node.js version lodash-node (2.4.1) takes 90-95 ms to load. Being able to load functions separately is nice, but when require()-ing full library the loading time could be better. For the sake of comparison, underscore for node on the same machine takes ~4-5ms to load.

Specific scenario where it's an issue is cluster/forked processes, currently spawning new worker process is about 2 times faster than loading lodash-node into the new context.

title: Switch 3rd party `underscore` dependencies with `lodash`
body:
I know this is not a issue with the `lodash` project itself, but maybe someone here knows how to achieve the following:

I want to use Backbone and other Backbone-related modules on the server side in Node.js. All these modules have set in their dependencies the `underscore` module. I am already using `lodash` for other parts of the server application. I would like all the modules using `underscore` to actually use `lodash` or `lodash-node` instead.

I know this can be done in a browser environment using browserify or similar build tools. Is this doable in some way in Node.js also?

I know I could fork the modules and replace their dependencies, but I don't want to have to keep them in sync.

title: A template bug
body:
For example, I want to print out a string `<%= test %>`.

``` javascript
_.template('<%= "<%= test %>" %>', {})
```

This code will result an exception.

But for template language like php, this will work (short_open_tag enabled):

``` php
<?= '<?= test ?>' ?>
```

In the CodeCombat project, we replace `Math.random` with a deterministic pseudoRNG. This patch would allow us to get deterministic behavior out of `_.random` after we do the replacement.

Original issue here: https://github.com/codecombat/codecombat/issues/1210.

title: Proposal: _.instanceOf(obj, {function|String})
throttle should not equal debounce
body:
Current implementation has throttle calling debounce internally but the behavior should actually be different.

The Underscore [annotated docs](http://underscorejs.org/docs/underscore.html#section-71) do a nice job of describing the difference but here's a quick attempt.

Throttle - limit func to no more than 1 call every N milliseconds
Debounce - only allow func to execute again after it has not been called for N milliseconds

An example to illustrate the difference would be a function that is called every 100 milliseconds.  Assuming the Wait time is 500 ms with default options, the Throttle version should be called immediately and then again every 500 ms while the Debounce version should only be called once (the first time) and never again.

Edit: updated docs link to go straight to `_.throttle`

title: Proposal: _.times() if callback is a string
Wrong # of args for _.curry() in documentation
body:
The generated documentation for `_.curry()` doesn't include the second argument (in the synopsis/header part):

http://lodash.com/docs#curry

I suspect this is caused by a bug/feature in jsdoc, as it seems unable to handle optional arguments with listed default values:

```
* @param {number} [arity=func.length] The arity of `func`.
```

Perhaps the following would work better? Don't know, since I haven't really tested... :smiley: 

```
* @param {number} [arity] The arity of `func` (defaults to `func.length`).
```

**Note:** I'd guess that this issue might show up on other places in the docs as well. Perhaps worth to try some clever `git grep` searches or similar.

As soon as lodash provides  `assign/extend` for mixins and `compose`, `forward` and `delegate` could be added

title: bower.json should reference modern instead of compat as main?
body:
According to [this Kit Cambridge blog post](http://kitcambridge.be/blog/custom-builds-in-lo-dash-2-dot-0/):

"Following jQuerys lead, were encouraging the adoption of the **modern build as the default**. Although the compat and legacy builds provide consistent support for legacy environments, we want to avoid penalizing newer implementations with redundant backward-compatibility fixes."

Given that position, I'd be less surprised to find that the project's bower.json include ...
`"main": "dist/lodash.js"`
... in place of ...
`"main": "dist/lodash.compat.js"`.

The reason I care at all: We're using [grunt-wiredep](https://www.npmjs.org/package/grunt-wiredep) to insert requests for bower-declared dependencies into our html, and it seems to be using that `main` value to determine which file to request.

title: Throttle Shouldn't return last value
body: The throttle function and debounce functions shouldn't return the last value that was returned by the original function. The reason I think they shouldn't is because theres no way for us to know if the function ran or not by the return value.

title: Add a `_.replicate` Array function
body:
This function replicates each element of an array `n` times:

```
_.replicate([1, 2, 3], 2) //=> [1, 1, 2, 2, 3, 3]
```

I find it useful for when you have to do something where two arrays have to match or have to be the same length or where each element of one should match each element of the other and so on. I don't know if it can be general enough to be merged into Lodash's core.

title: Improved documentation for lodash code completion
body:
In the lodash constructor function:

```
add this before the comment:
        /**
         * @name _
         */

and change @name _ from the comment itself to @lends _ (or @alias, but lodash uses it for other things)
```

The result is that now ctrl+clicking on a lodash function (e.g. _.forEach -> clicking on forEach) will now link only to the lodash implementation, and won't clash with other 'forEach' or other function implementations from the project using lodash.

_ will still lead to the same spot in the code

Finally, change all Note: from the comments to Note! or Note// or anything except for a semicolon. IDEs such as IDEA and Webstorm (at least, maybe others) parse the jsdoc for 'something: description' as a parameter name for a function, so all functions with Note: in the documentation have 'Note' show up as the first parameter in the function

I can provide screenshots if needed, but it seems to work much better than before like this.

title: Production-ready versions?
body:
Hey @jdalton , 

As I see it, the current build is 2.4.1 and the repository is on 3.0.0-pre, which is labeled as a WIP.

If not, I'd like to port over some changes (& their tests, of course) to the 2.4.x branch and create a build (2.4.2) - is this welcome?

Specifically, I'm looking for these from 3.0:
--Added cancel method to debounced & throttled functions
--Allowed _.sortBy to accept an array of property names to sort by
--Ensured _.isEqual works with plain objects containing function constructor properties
--Ensured _.where only returns elements that contain all source array/object values

Though even if I could only take the cancel for debounce, I would be happy.

title: support.ownLast is "false" in all but IE < 9
body: support.ownLast is "false" in all but IE < 9. I guess a short way to describe that is "none but IE < 9" but having "all but IE < 9" is misleading. As the rest of the support properties (e.g. funcNames) return "true" when you have a browser that fits in the "all" part.

title: A typo in documentation for _.pick
body:
Probably there is a typo at [pick](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/tree/master/doc#_pickobject-callback-thisarg):

```
of object picking the properties the callback returns truey for
```

**truey** is likely supposed to be either **true** or **truthy**

title: _.cloneDeep of MongoDB ObjectId results in malformed object.
body:
When performing a _.cloneDeep on an object containing an attribute with a value of a MongoDB ObjectId type, the cloned result is malformed.

The result looks like: 
```js
"_id":{_bsontype:"ObjectID",id:"SlW\u0005\u0000\u0000\u0007\u000f"}
```
When the original looks like: 
```js
"_id": "53add57c097b3e0000f3b985"
```
This causes issues when performing transitions such as toString() on the attribute. On the original it will produce `"53add57c097b3e0000f3b985"`, and on the cloneDeep version it will produce `"[object Object]"`.

title: "strict" option for _.once?
body:
I'd like it if `_.once` took an optional extra argument, where if you pass `true` (`_.once(true, fn)`), it would throw an error if you call the function more than once (as opposed to the usual behaviour of silently ignoring subsequent calls).

I quite often implement this kind of 'strict once' function manually when I'm writing an asynchronous function where I call `done()` in several different places (to cover different outcomes), and I want to ensure that there's no possible code paths that could result in `done` being called more than once. It's kind of an inline assertion, where you know that calling it more than once would be a bug. Not so much for production code, but useful when initially hacking out an asynchronous deploy script or something. It would be nice if lodash could handle this for me.

title: zip fails for single arguments
body:
When calling `zip` with single arguments, lodash tries to unzip it, which leads to some single-argument zips being handled wrongly.

```
> _.zip([1, 2], [3, 4], [5, 6])
[[1, 3, 5], [2, 4, 6]]

> _.zip([1, 2], [3, 4])
[[1, 3], [2, 4]]

> _.zip([1, 2])
[]
```

this was extremely unexpected for me.

title: _.contains feature | searching for object properties in array
.lastIndexOf with negative from idx
body:
Continuing discussion https://github.com/jashkenas/underscore/issues/1705

It looks like you have an inconsistency handling `fromIdx+length < 0` you set it to `0`

So

```
_.lastIndexOf([1, 2, 3], 1, -4); // => 0
_.lastIndexOf([1, 2, 3], 2, -4); // => -1
```

I'd propose something like

```
if (typeof fromIndex == 'number') {
  index = (fromIndex < 0 ? index + fromIndex : nativeMin(fromIndex || 0, index - 1)) + 1;
  if (index < 0) index = length;
}
```

title: Regarding lodash-amd dependence on the global `window` object.
body:
This issue originally popped up here: https://github.com/tbranyen/lodash-template-loader/issues/9 where my recommendation was to use lodash-node.

I just recently tried optimizing a project that uses lodash-amd and found the same issue occurs.  While this is easily mitigated in our codebase, it made me wonder more about the AMD builds.

It seems unintuitive to have AMD be specifically geared towards the browser.  Especially since AMD works fine in all mainstream JavaScript environments.

Specific offender:
- https://github.com/lodash/lodash-amd/blob/master/modern/support.js#L18

title: New method: mergeCollection
_.where with array of values has unclear behavior
body:
Given this example:

```
var characters = [
  { 'name': 'barney', 'age': 36, 'pets': ['hoppy'] },
  { 'name': 'fred',   'age': 40, 'pets': ['baby puss', 'dino'] }
];

_.where(characters, { 'pets': ['dino', 'hoppy'] });
```

I would expect one of the following 2 scenarios:
1. It would return characters that have a pets array that includes BOTH  (i.e. && op) dino and hoppy - since none exist, it would return an empty array
-OR-
2. It would return characters that have a pets array that includes EITHER dino OR hoppy (i.e. || op), and would therefore return both.

The actual result? It only looks at the first item in the array, so it returns any character that has a pet 'dino'.

In other words:

```
_.where(characters, { 'pets': ['dino', 'hoppy', 'sadasdadasdsa', 'asdasdasd'] }) === _.where(characters, { 'pets': ['dino'] })
```

Finally, `_.where` actually performs an && comparison for everything else, i.e.:

``` js
var characters = [
  { 'name': 'barney', 'married': true, 'age': 36, 'pets': ['hoppy'] },
  { 'name': 'fred', 'married': false,  'age': 40, 'pets': ['hoppy'] }
];

_.where(characters, { 'married': true, 'pets': ['hoppy'] });
```

Will return characters where `character.married === true && _.contains(character.pets, 'hoppy')`

So I think this should stay consistent, and return true only for whoever has all of the pets that are specified.

What do you think?

If yes, I'd like to try to fix this and submit a pull request

title: _.difference and _.merge on two different arrays with common elements
body:
I don't know how those functions should work, but this:

``` javascript
_.merge(['asd', 'asd', 1], ['asd', 'asd', 2])
```

don't return `['asd', 'asd', 1, 2]` but `["asd", "asd", 2]`. And:

``` javascript
_.difference(['asd', 'asd', 1], ['asd', 'asd', 2])
```

return `[1]` instead of `[1,2]`.

Is that how those function should work? I'm using version 2.2.1

title: CommonJS export is weird
body:
I'm using Browserify to bundle a custom build of lodash.

```
$ lodash --debug --output app/scripts/vendor/lodash.custom.js backbone exports=commonjs
```

``` js
var _ = require('./vendor/lodash.custom.js');
```

But it doesn't work like other modules. It turns out my lodash build doesn't set `module.exports` to lodash; instead it exports it as `exports._`. So with the above code, you have to do `_._.each()`, etc.

Or you can do `var _ = require('./lodash.custom.js')._;`. But why? Why doesn't it just follow the normal convention and export it directly?

It seems a bit of effort is needed to gracefully handle such a situation. This functionality is something I find myself needed pretty much every project that deals with a JSON API. This would would be right at home in a utility belt like lodash.

Something kind of like:
https://github.com/wilmoore/selectn

Some discussion:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2631001/javascript-test-for-existence-of-nested-object-key

title: _.filter can now accept an array of callbacks
partially applied function fails over map
body:
When a apply a `partialRight` to `has` and then `map` it I get unexpected behavior.

`hasKey2` fails when I add it to a mapped function. Not sure if this expected behavior or not. `hasKey` was the behavior I was expecting.    

```
var a = [{'key':'value'}, {'noKey': 'anotherValue'}]

var hasKey = function(o) {
    return _.has(o, 'key')
}
var hasKey2 = _.partialRight(_.has, 'key')

console.log(_.map(a, hasKey))
console.log(_.map(a, hasKey2))
```

Expected results for both functions.

```
[true, false]
```

`hasKey2` results:

```
[false, false] 
```

title: _.has inconsistent across browsers when checking for DOM Object attributes
body:
My team ran into this issue today. The following prints `true` in Chrome and `false` in FireFox:

``` js
var a = document.getElementById('someElementId');
console.log(_.has(a, 'href'));
```

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/18478913/hasownproperty-htmlelement-firefox
According to this Stack Overflow thread, the reason is because Chrome sets html attributes directly to `HTMLElement.prototype` and Firefox does not, so hasOwnProperty is returning a different value in different browsers.

Should `_.has` be updated to provide a consistent experience across browsers?

title: Updated README.md
body: This commit adds links to Lo-Dash documentation under a specific "Documentation" heading, hopefully improving usability for users searching for the API docs.

title: Cancelling a debounced call
body:
It would be great if there were a way to cancel a debounced call. Say the debounced method is called, it waits 1second before it gets executed, however before it gets executed the object on which the original method exists has to be destroyed getting you into problems with destroying the object and even keeping the GC from cleaning it up.

To get around this it would be good if we could cancel a potentially running debounced call by internally clearing the timeout id.

title: Make `_.escape` escape backticks as well
body: In Internet Explorer  8, the backtick character can be used to break out of quoted attribute values or HTML comments. See http://html5sec.org/#102, http://html5sec.org/#108, and http://html5sec.org/#133.

title: Question about _.snakeCase behaviour.
Documentation: omit is not chainable
body: The documentation comment for the lodash function (lodash.js L679) indicates that "omit" is chainable, but it is not.  It returns an object without the indicated key, not a wrapper.  The documentation should be updated.  (I did not check for other mistakes; I just noticed that one while porting some code from underscore.)

Also please add it to the bower registry.

title: Bracket value function
body:
Would a utility function for forcing a value to be between a specified min & max value be a suitable enhancement to lodash?

Something like `_.bracket(minVal, maxVal)`, possibly with a third optional 'default' parameter that it will be set to if the value is null or unknown.

title: Add _.defaultsDeep
body:
I just came across this in the docs (as an example of how to use partialRight):

```
defaultsDeep = _.partialRight(_.merge, _.defaults);
```

Given how small, useful and unobvious this implementation of a deep extend method is why not add it as a method?

title: Add `_.existy` to define objects existance.
body:
`existy` checks if `arguments` contains `undefined` or `null` values, if so (or if no arguments are passed) it returns false, otherwise it returns true.

Example:

``` javascript
if (_.existy(iNeedToChekThis, andThis, andThat)) {
  // do something with those
}
```

I'm using lodash a lot both server and frontend side, I've created a small library to have `existy` and `truthy` as a help in some repetitive checks but I believe they belong in here. Credits to Michael Fogus for those two functions.

Please let me know if something is wrong in what I did or if it could be written in a better way.
If this is ok I would be happy to also add `truthy` to lodash.

Thanks for this project.

title: Memory leak during _.bind
Add a smart 'toString' method to object
body:
Hi there,

I think an smart toString method would be nice for many people. By smart, I mean :
- applied to objet it returns all key=values of the object,
- manage correctly circular reference,
- can provide the list of functions (this could be an option).

It should be near the JSON.stringify method but with the support of circular reference.

See more examples and solutions proposed by community here : http://stackoverflow.com/questions/957537/how-can-i-print-a-javascript-object

--- EDIT ----
In fact I need a "inspect" method like provided by Node.js util library. http://nodejs.org/api/util.html#util_util_inspect_object_options

JM.

title: Addition of _.parseBoolean method in utilites
body:
I've recently started using lodash and one function I'm missing that I frequently use is one to parse boolean values, typically from strings.

So here is one I'd like to add, if you think it would be a worthwhile addition. 

The function has no side effects and tests are passing across major browsers and in node.

title: First example for _.times() is incorrect.
body:
In the documentation, the first example for `_.times()` is:

``` javascript
var diceRolls = _.times(3, _.partial(_.random, 1, 6));
//  [3, 6, 4]
```

However, because `_.times()` passes `index` to the callback, it actually returns something like:

``` javascript
[4, 3.8181065060198307, 3.105474406853318]
```

The example should probably be changed to:

``` javascript
var diceRolls = _.times(3, _.partial(_.random, 1, 6, false));
//  [3, 6, 4]
```

title: Added '_.round' function for rounding values to arbitrary decimal places...
body:
Thought I'd have a go at contributing. Fantastic library.

Not 100% on whether this fits with lodash as a whole, but I thought I'd try. Hopefully everything is inline with how you guys do things around here :)

Any feedback is appreciated!

Thanks,
Dave

title: _.some() invoked as backbone collection method returns wrong result
body:
`collection.some({'test': true})` returns false (wrong)
`_.some(collection.toJSON(), {'test': true})` returns true (right)

I created a jsbin for that:
http://jsbin.com/ticomape/3/watch?html,js,console

Any ideas why this is happening?

title: Add _.isPartOf/_.isIncluded
Feature request: Remove consecutive duplicates
body:
# uniq is great for removing duplicates.  But from time to time we need to remove consecutive duplicates only.  Given the following:

[a, a, b, c, d, d, a, b, c, b, b, d]

Applying a function called, say, _.removeConsecutiveDups, we would have

[a, b, c, d, a, b, c, b, d]

I've run across the need for this quite a few times, most recently in the context of undo/redo.  With undo/redo implementations, it is not desirable to have consecutive commands on the undo stack whose states are equal.

Just an idea...

title: should wrapped arrays support ember polyfills and convenience methods (like underscore)?
body:
Ember extends Array.prototype with several methods (see http://emberjs.com/guides/configuring-ember/disabling-prototype-extensions/).

When ember.js has been included, the following works on underscore but fails on lodash:

```
_([]).pushObjects([1])

```

`[].pushObjects([1])` works on both, using the pushObjects method added to Array.prototype by ember.

title: Add spm support in package.json
body:
Another great package manager: http://spmjs.io
Documentation: http://spmjs.io/documentation

http://spmjs.io/package/lodash

title: Pass the original index in the array into the function
body:
I recently came into a situation where I needed to use the original array index in `_.remove`

Current functionality was passing in the current index in the modified array
So if you were removing every value in the array, index would always be 0

I have made the change to pass the original index instead of the currentIndex as I couldn't figure out what anyone would get out of using the currentIndex, most of the time you will just use the value instead of this[index]...but I might be missing something

title: Fix old `pullAt` example
body: Small correction.

title: unexpected behaviour of _.merge with _.defaults callback
API docs broken with certain Chrome extensions
body:
Viewing http://lodash.com/docs

I have a particular Chrome extension called Stayfocused which injects a Div into the body, and as a result the CSS rule `#docs body>div:nth-child(3) {` applies to the wrong element, essentially making the page unreadable (see screenshot).

![capture](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/783281/2853055/0b72df3e-d13f-11e3-8f91-144dc40b334e.PNG)

(EDIT: Just realised my screenshot includes Inspector-modified CSS rules to make the page readable, in case that further confused the issue :)

Whilst this is arguably the fault of the Chrome extension, the CSS rule could obviously be more robust. Given that the first impression is that the person who wrote the CSS is careless, it might be advisable to make it a little more forgiving of clumsy extensions?

Given the purpose of the extension I don't quite understand why it is injecting here, or whether it is alone in this method.

title: Deapply / unapply / preapply function
Push into a sorted array
body: If I want to add an element into a sorted array, I push it and then sort the whole array. I guess there may be a better way.

title: Strange _.where() behavior with array of objects each with property that is also array of objects
Provide a _.fill method to merge in missing attribute in a destination object from sources, but not overwrite existing values
`_.parseInt` and ES6 octal/binary integer literals
body:
Should `_.parseInt` support ES6 octal/binary integer literals such as `0b1011` and `0o42`?

Note that native `parseInt()` wont support these to avoid backwards compatibility issues.
